nodes.text: CUSZP2 is a pure-GPU, single-kernel error-bounded lossy compressor that achieves extreme end-to-end throughput and optimized compression ratios for HPC and ML workloads
CUSZP2 attains extreme end-to-end throughput (compression and decompression) by eliminating CPU-GPU data movement, optimizing memory accesses, and hiding synchronization latency
CUSZP2 achieves optimized compression ratios (better than state-of-the-art GPU compressors in most cases) while preserving high reconstructed data quality

CUSZP2 design is a single GPU-kernel workflow operating on block granularity (lossy conversion, lossless encoding, global prefix-sum, block concatenation) enabling vectorized I/O and in-kernel synchronization techniques
Method: Outlier fixed-length encoding (Outlier-FLE) selectively encodes blocks using an outlier-preserving fixed-length mode to reduce stored bits for smooth blocks
Method: Vectorized memory accesses within blocks (use vector types) and coalesced block-level accesses across warps to reduce memory instructions and maximize global memory bandwidth
Method: Global prefix-sum via decoupled lookback, a compression-aware adaptive lookback strategy that decouples chained scan and hides device-level synchronization latency

Evidence/Result: Measured end-to-end throughput on NVIDIA A100 (9 real-world HPC datasets): average compression 332.42 GB/s and decompression 513.04 GB/s, typically about 2x faster than other pure-GPU compressors and ~200x faster than CPU-GPU hybrid designs

Evidence/Result: Memory bandwidth utilization for CUSZP2 reaches ~1100-1175 GB/s on A100 (near hardware limit 1555 GB/s) versus 134-410 GB/s for baseline pure-GPU compressors, validating vectorized/coalesced accesses

Evidence/Result: Compression ratio results across datasets show CUSZP2 with Outlier-FLE has the highest compression ratio in 24 of 27 evaluated cases and often substantially higher ratios on smooth or sparse datasets

Evidence/Result: Reconstructed data quality: CUSZP2 preserves high-quality isosurfaces and yields best rate-distortion among error-bounded GPU compressors; compared with cuZFP, CUSZP2 preserves features better at aggressive compression ratios

Method: Single-kernel workflow compresses blocks then concatenates into a unified byte array on device, includes lossy conversion to quantized integers and two lossless modes (Plain-FLE and Outlier-FLE)
Evidence/Result: Synchronization performance: decoupled lookback achieves 846.85 GB/s device-level prefix-sum throughput (2.41x of plain chained-scan), reducing latency during block concatenation

Claim/Design Rationale: 1D first-order difference processing (blockwise) is chosen to balance throughput and compression ratio because higher-dimension (2D/3D) differences increase memory complexity and reduce throughput despite sometimes improving ratio

Evidence/Result: Additional capabilities and portability: CUSZP2 supports double-precision datasets with increased throughput (e.g., 612.83-809.71 GB/s), random block access at TB-level throughput (~1010 GB/s average), and consistent ~2x speedups on lower-end NVIDIA GPUs (RTX 3090/3080)
